app_description: Welcome to Tajweed Recognition - An innovative application utilizing OCR technology to distinguish various rules of Tajweed within Arabic text on images, accompanied by color highlighting of Tajweed and interactive explanations for easier learning.

tajweed_laws.name: Idzhar
tajweed_laws.summary: Idzhar/Idzhar Halqi tajweed law happens when a nun sakinah or tanwin meets the letters of idzhar (ا ع غ ح خ ها), it is pronounced clearly and distinctly.
tajweed_laws.detail: The letters of idzhar are pronounced clearly because their point of articulation is the mouth and they are in the throat.
examples: مِنْ آَلِ فِرْعَوْنَ  Nun sakinah meets أ
فَكُلُوا مِنْهَا حَيْثُ Nun sakinah meets هـ
بِغَافِلٍ عَمَّا تَعْمَلُونَ Nun sakinah meets ع
مِنْ غَفُورٍ رَحِيم Nun sakinah meets غ
أَنَّ اللَّهَ عَزِيزٌ حَكِيمٌ Tanwin meets ح
كُونُوا قِرَدَةً خَاسِئِينَ Tanwin meets خ

tajweed_laws.name: Idgham Bigunnah
tajweed_laws.summary: Idgham Bigunnah tajweed law happens when a nun sakinah or tanwin meets the letters of idgham bigunnah (ي ن م و), it is pronounced with a nasal sound.
tajweed_laws.detail: Idgham means to merge, and bigunnah means nasal sound. So the letters of idgham bigunnah are pronounced with a nasal sound.
examples: مِنْ قَبْلِ أَنْ يَتَمَاسَّا Nun sakinah meets ي
إِلَّا سَاعَةً مِنْ نَهَارٍ Nun sakinah meets ن
وَأَنْفِقُوا مِنْ مَا رَزَقْنَاكُمْ Nun sakinah meets م
مِنْ دُونِهِ مِنْ وَالٍ Nun sakinah meets و
بِبُهْتَانٍ يَفْتَرِينَهُ Tanwin meets ي
حِطَّةٌ نَغْفِرْ لَكُمْ Tanwin meets ن
رَقَبَةٍ مِنْ قَبْلِ Tanwin meets م
مِنْ خَيْلٍ وَلَا رِكَابٍ Tanwin meets و

tajweed_laws.name: Idgham Bilagunnah
tajweed_laws.summary: Idgham Bilagunnah tajweed law happens when a nun sakinah or tanwin meets the letters of idgham bilagunnah (ل ر), it is pronounced by merging without nasal sound.
tajweed_laws.detail: Idgham means to merge, and bilagunnah means without nasal sound. So the letters of idgham bilagunnah are pronounced by merging without a nasal sound.
examples: فَضْلًا مِنْ رَبِّكَ Nun sakinah meets ر
قَالَ لَمْ أَكُنْ لِأَسْجُدَ Nun sakinah meets ل
لَا تَجْعَلْنَا فِتْنَةً لِلَّذِينَ Tanwin meets ل
سَيَقُولُونَ ثَلَاثَةٌ رَابِعُهُمْ Tanwin meets ر

tajweed_laws.name: Iqlab
tajweed_laws.summary: Iqlab tajweed law happens when a nun sakinah or tanwin meets the letter of iqlab (ب), it is pronounced by replacing it with the letter mim.
tajweed_laws.detail: Iqlab means to merge or, in simpler terms, to replace the letter with the letter mim.
examples: أَنْ تُنْبِتُوا Nun sakinah meets ب
كُلُّ حِزْبٍ بِمَا Tanwin meets ب

tajweed_laws.name: Ikhfa
tajweed_laws.summary: Ikhfa/Ikhfa Haqiqi tajweed law happens when a nun sakinah or tanwin meets the letters of ikhfa haqiqi (ت ث ج د ذ ز س ش ص ض ط ظ ف ق ك), it is pronounced softly.
tajweed_laws.detail: Ikhfa means to conceal or hide, while haqiqi means real or true. So the letters of ikhfa haqiqi are pronounced softly.
examples: أَنْتُمْ Nun sakinah meets ت
مَنْثُورًا Nun sakinah meets ث
فَأَنْجَيْنَاه Nun sakinah meets ج
عِنْدَهُ Nun sakinah meets د
لِيُنْذِرَكُمْ Nun sakinah meets ذ
أُنْزِلَ Nun sakinah meets ز
نَنْسَخْ Nun sakinah meets س
مَنْشُورً Nun sakinah meets ش
رِيحًا صَرْصَرًا Tanwin meets ص
وَكُلًّا ضَرَبْنَا Tanwin meets ض
صَعِيدًا طَيِّبًا Tanwin meets ط
ظِلًّا ظَلِيلً Tanwin meets ظ
سَفَرٍ فَعِدَّةٌ Tanwin meets ف
عَلِيمٌ قَدِيرٌ Tanwin meets ق
وَرِزْقٌ كَرِيمٌ Tanwin meets ك

tajweed_laws.name: Idzhar Syafawi
tajweed_laws.summary: Idzhar Syafawi tajweed law happens when a mim sakinah meets the letters of idzhar syafawi (ا ت ث ج ح خ د ذ ر ز س ش ص ض ط ظ ع غ ف ق ك ل ن و ه ي), it must be pronounced clearly even with closed lips.
tajweed_laws.detail: The letters of idzhar syafawi are so many, except for mim and ba, because the two letters are owned by ikhfa syafawi and idgham mimi.
examples: أَأَنْذَرْتَهُمْ أَم Mim sakinah meets ا
أَنْعَمْتَ Mim sakinah meets ت
ثُمَّ يُمِيتُكُمْ ثُمَّ يُحْيِيكُمْ Mim sakinah meets ث
أَنَّ لَهُمْ جَنَّاتٍ Mim sakinah meets ج
يَمْحَقُ اللَّهُ الرِّبَا Mim sakinah meets ح

tajweed_laws.name: Ikhfa Syafawi
tajweed_laws.summary: Ikhfa Syafawi tajweed law happens when a mim sakinah meets the letters of ikhfa syafawi (ب), it is pronounced softly by disguising the sound with a nasal tone.
tajweed_laws.detail: Although the nasal sound isn't very clear because the letters Mim Sakinah and Ba have the same exit point, namely two lips. There is only one letter for Ikhfa Syafawi. The letters are the same as iqlab, but the way to read them is not merged like iqlab.
examples: وَمَا هُمْ بِمُؤْمِنِينَ Mim sakinah meets the letter of ب
وَهُمْ بِالْآَخِرَةِ Mim sakinah meets the letter of ب
عَلَيْهِمْ بِعِلْمٍMim sakinah meets the letter of ب

tajweed_laws.name: Idgham Mimi
tajweed_laws.summary: Idgham Mimi tajweed law happens when mim sakinah meets the letters of idgham mimi (م), it is pronounced in the same way as mim tasydid.
tajweed_laws.detail: The letter of Idgham Mimi is only one. The letter is mim. So, Idgham Mimi is the meeting of two mim letters. The way to pronounce it is the same as pronouncing the mim with tasydid. Because, mim tasydid is a combination of mim sakinah and mim with harakah.
examples: وَكَمْ مِنْ قَرْيَةٍ Mim sakinah meets م
كُلَّمَا أَضَاءَ لَهُمْ مَشَوْا فِيهِ Mim sakinah meets م
إِلَيْكُمْ مِنْ رَبِّكُمْ Mim sakinah meets م

tajweed_laws.name: Gunnah
tajweed_laws.summary: Gunnah tajweed law happens if there is a shaddah on the letter mim (مّ) and nun (ن), it is pronounced with a nasal sound and is called Ghunnah.
tajweed_laws.detail: Ghunnah means: nasaling (at the bridge of the nose). So the way to read it is by humming the letters mim and nun taysdid on the bridge of the nose for 2 - 3 harakah.

tajweed_laws.name: Idgham Mutamasilain
tajweed_laws.summary: Idgham Mutamasilain tajweed law happens when a letter meets a similar letter, with the same makhraj and characteristic, where the first letter is sukun (silent) and the second letter has a harakah.
tajweed_laws.detail: The way to read it is by inserting the first sukun letter into the second harokah letter. And being pressured, he was detained for no more than one harokah

tajweed_laws.name: Idgham Mutajaanisain
tajweed_laws.summary: Idgham Mutajaanisain tajweed law happens if there is a letter with the meaning of sukun opposite a letter with the meaning of harakah, both have the same makhroj but have different characteristics.
tajweed_laws.detail: The way to read it is by inserting or idghom the first letter in the second letter.

tajweed_laws.name: Idgham Mutaqooribain
tajweed_laws.summary: Idgham Mutaqooribain tajweed law happens if a letter with a sukun meets a letter with a harakah, the two letters are close to each other, makhroj and its properties.
tajweed_laws.detail: The way to read it is by inserting or adding the first letter to the second letter.

tajweed_laws.name: Idzhar Qamariyah
tajweed_laws.summary: Idzhar Qamariyah tajweed law happens when a lam ta’rief meets the letters of idzhar qamariyah (ء ب ج ح خ ع غ ف ق ك م و ه ي), it must be pronounced clearly.
tajweed_laws.detail: Qamar in Arabic means moon. Meanwhile, lam ta'rief is likened to a star. This is because the stars remain visible even though they meet the moon.
examples: لَكُمُ الْأَرْضَ ذَلُولً Alif lam meets ء
فَارْجِعِ الْبَصَرَ Alif lam meets ب
أَصْحَابَ الْجَنَّةِ Alif lam meets ج
خَلَقَ الْمَوْتَ وَالْحَيَاةَ Alif lam meets ح
وَهُوَ اللَّطِيفُ الْخَبِيرُ Alif lam meets خ

tajweed_laws.name: Idgham Syamsiyah
tajweed_laws.summary: Idgham Syamsiyah tajweed law happens when a lam ta’rief meets the letters of qamariyah, other than idzhar qamariyah (ت ث د ذ ر ز س ش ص ض ط ظ ل ن), it is called idgham.
tajweed_laws.detail: Syamsiyah means sun, so if Alif Lam, which is likened to a star, meets the sun, it becomes less visible. Because this is not readable, the alif lam which meets the syamsiyah letters, seems to be tasydid, or inserted into the next letter.
examples: وَأَنْزَلَ التَّوْرَاةَ Alif lam meets ت
مِنَ الثَّمَرَاتِ Alif lam meets ث
يَوْمِ الدِّينِ Alif lam meets د
وَالذَّاكِرِينَ Alif lam meets ذ
الرَّحْمَنِ Alif lam meets ر

tajweed_laws.name: Tafkhim
tajweed_laws.summary: Tafkhim tajweed law happens when there is the letter lam (ل) in the word Allah (اللّه) preceded by a letter with a Fathah or Dammah vowel.
tajweed_laws.detail: It must be recited thickly or with Tafkhim, which is done by lifting the entire tongue and pressing it against the upper palate while emphasizing the sound strongly.

tajweed_laws.name: Tarqiq
tajweed_laws.summary: Tarqiq tajweed law happens when there is the letter lam (ل) in the word Allah (اللّه) preceded by a letter with a Kasrah vowel.
tajweed_laws.detail: It must be recited thinly or with Tarqiq

tajweed_laws.name: Qalqalah Sughra
tajweed_laws.summary: Qalqalah Sughra tajweed law happens if there is a silent qalqalah letter (ب ج د ط ق) in the middle of a sentence, it is pronounced with a bounce. It is read as qalqalah sughra.
tajweed_laws.detail: Qalqalah sughra is read thinner, like the meaning of sughra itself which means small.
examples: ثُمَّ لِيَقْطَعْ فَلْيَنْظُرْ There is a Qaf sakinah letter in the middle of the word
ثَانِيَ عِطْفِهِ  There is a Tho sakinah letter in the middle of the word
وَقَوْمُ إِبْرَاهِيمَ There is a Ba sakinah letter in the middle of the word
فَعَلَيَّ إِجْرَامِي There is a Ja sakinah letter in the middle of the word
يَدْعُو مِنْ دُونِ اللَّهِ  There is a Da sakinah letter in the meiddle of the word

tajweed_laws.name: Qalqalah Kubra
tajweed_laws.summary: Qalqalah Kubra tajweed law happens if there is a silent qalqalah letter (ب ج د ط ق) at the end of a sentence, it is pronounced with a bounce. It is read as qalqalah kubro.
tajweed_laws.detail: Qalqalah kubro, how to read it, is reflected more clearly and louder, like the meaning of kubro which means big.
examples: بَيْنِ الصُّلْبِ وَالتَّرَائِبِ There is a Ba letter in the end of the sentence
وَالسَّمَاءِ ذَاتِ الْبُرُوجِ There is a Ja letter in the end of the sentence
وَالْيَوْمِ الْمَوْعُودِ There is a Da letter in the end of the sentence
قَائِمًا بِالْقِسْطِ There is a Tho letter in the end of the sentence
وَالسَّمَاءِ وَالطَّارِقِ There is a Qaf letter in the end of the sentence

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Thabii
tajweed_laws.summary: The law of reading is called Mad Thobi'i, that is, if the letter whose sound is extended is a letter with the harokat Dlommah (ُ) and after it there is the letter Wau Sukun (ﻭْ), a letter with the harokat kasroh and after that there is the letter Yaa' Sukun (ﻱْ), a letter with the harokat fathah (َ) and after that there is the letter Alif (ا)

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Wajib Muttasil
tajweed_laws.summary: Mad Wajib Muttasil tajweed law happens if Mad Thobi'i meets a living Hamzah (ء) within a word/sentence, it is mandatory to prolong it.
tajweed_laws.detail: The way to read it must be extended to two and a half Alif or five harokat or two and a half times the length of Mad Thobi'i.

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Jaiz Munfassil
tajweed_laws.summary: The recitation rule is called Mad Jaiz Munfashil when Mad Thobi'i (ء) is in a different word.
tajweed_laws.detail: The way to read it is better to extend it like the length of Mad Wajib Muttashil, but also may be extended like the length of Mad Thobi'i.

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Lazim Mutsaqqal Kilmi
tajweed_laws.summary: Mad Lazim Mutsaqqal Kilmi tajweed law happens if Mad Thobi'i is faced with letters with shaddah within a word.
tajweed_laws.detail: The pronunciation should be prolonged first for 3 alif or 6 harakah before shaddah is added.

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Lazim Mukhaffaf Kilmi
tajweed_laws.summary: Mad Lazim Mukhaffaf Kilmi tajweed law happens if Mad Thobi'i meets a sukun-harokat letter not at the end of a word. (prolonged up to three alif or six harakah).
tajweed_laws.detail: The way to read it is like Mad Lazim Mutsaqqol Kilmi (extended to three alif or six harakah).

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Layyin
tajweed_laws.summary: Mad Layyin tajweed law happens if there is a Mad letter, whether it is Wau Sukun (ﻭْ) or Yaa' Sukun (ﻱْ) preceded by a fathah-harokat letter.
tajweed_laws.detail: It is pronounced softly and smoothly.

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Arid Lissukun
tajweed_laws.summary: Mad Arid Lissukun tajweed law happens if there is Mad Thobi'i or Mad Layyin followed by a waqof (stopping place).
tajweed_laws.detail:
There are 3 ways to read it:
a. What is more important is that it is read long, the same as Mad Wajib Mutashil (three alif or six harakah).
b. The middle (medium) one can only be read as two Alif or four harokats (twice Mad Thobi'i).
c. The sortest one may be only read as Mad Thobi'i (two harakah).

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Shilah Qashirah
tajweed_laws.summary: Mad Shilah Qashirah tajweed law happens if the letter Haa Dlomir/third person pronoun (noun) comes (ه) after a vowel-harokat letter and is not connected to a sukun or shaddah letter or the letter alif.
tajweed_laws.detail: The way to read it is extended to one Alif or two harokat or like the length of Mad Thobi 'ii.

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Shilah Thawilah
tajweed_laws.summary: Mad Shilah Thawilah tajweed law happens if Mad Shilah Qoshiroh meets Hamzah (ء) preceded by a vowel-harokat letter.
tajweed_laws.detail: The way to read it is like reading Mad Jaiz Munfashil, meaning it can be extended to two and a half Alif or one Alif like Mad Thobi 'ii.

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Iwad
tajweed_laws.summary: Mad Iwad tajweed law happens if there is fathatain vowels (ً) falling on waqof (pause), at the end of a sentence (except for ta' marbuthoh), or mentioned as a replacement for tanwin so that it is no longer pronounced.
tajweed_laws.detail: The way to read it is extended one Alif like Mad Thobi'ii.

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Badal
tajweed_laws.summary: Mad Badal tajweed law happens if Hamzah (ء) meets Mad from a sukun-hamzah, and this hamzah is changed and replaced with Alif (ا), Wau (ﻭ).
tajweed_laws.detail: It is pronounced by prolonging it for one alif or two harakah, like Mad Thobi'ii.

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Tamkin
tajweed_laws.summary: The recitation rule called Mad Tamkin occurs when there is a Yaa' Sukun (ﻱْ) preceded by a Yaa' with shaddah and a Kasrah vowel (ﻱِ).
tajweed_laws.detail: The reading is established with shaddah and its natural Mad is extended to the length of two vowels or one alif.

tajweed_laws.name: Mad Farq
tajweed_laws.summary: The reading rule called Mad Farq is a Mad that in the Quran only occurs in four places.
tajweed_laws.detail: The reading must be elongated to distinguish between a question or not, so the elongation makes it clear that the sentence is in the form of a question.
